Honorable John Davis, Assistant Secretary of State:
Sir,
I now report my arrival at my station Oct. 22nd 1884 and my entry upon the duties of the office at that date. I found everything pertaining to the office had been carefully cared for by Rev. A.C. Good who was appointed to C.A. but who owing to certain aspect changes in our mission thought it not best to qualify as he might not be able to attend to the duties of the office. There has therefore been no official duties performed and the regular reports have not been sent
I have made an official call upon the Commandant and have *unclear lines8
gather <pb facs="20170615_145443" gather some forms regarding the policy of France in this Agency.
The present Commandant so friendly, personally, but insists upon the last being explored even while he presses expert that such lawd have been passed.
Bonita a distresal fourth Gaboon where are mission has been laboring nearly thirty years with mor sucess has lately been slammed both by the German and the French, the negatives *unclear* at Germans. The Commandant here has recounted orders from France to store the mission even before the claim of our business is allowed.
The French have wished to get posession of Consec Island never belonging to Spain, where our mission has been established for nearly forty years and the Commandant wrote to the people asking them to form the triangle from Spain + France. The people met and passed them
<pb facs="20170615_145449"
wishes by letter written by one of our native preachers, Rev. EBEA L. KING a native of Corises, in language more favorable than elegant and now the Commandant threatens to arrest and imprison him if he enters the Colony of Gaboon, He however expects to attend our nesting of Presbytert in Jan. end.
Towards the people here they are acting so as gradually to divest them of all power necessairly using very arbitrary measures and rejoicing that they are able to show the people that resistance is useless.
I feel that the next few years is going to decide the question, whether France is to be allowed to impose her unjust laws and arbitary restrictions upon a large pair of tropical Africa, or not; and I could wish that the voice of our own government might be heard protesting effectively in behalf of this down hidden people.
<pb facs="20170615_145458"
I have the honor to acknowledge the receipt of a cope of an act making appropritations for the consular and Diplomatic service of the government for the fiscal year ending June thirteth eighteen hundred and slightly five, and for other purposes.
I banshere with reports No. 10 for Quarterly ending June 3rd, 1883 and Nov.105 for fiscal years ending repeating June 30th, 1883+1884. I remain Sir,
Your obident servant Graham C. Campbell U.S.C.A
